term.title: intercalation reaction

item.text: Reaction, generally reversible, that involves the penetration of a host material by guest species without causing a major structural modification of the host.

notes.item: Intercalation can refer to the insertion of a guest species into a one-, two- or three-dimensional host structure.
The guest species is not distributed randomly but occupies positions predetermined by the structure of the host material.
Examples of intercalation reactions are the insertion of lithium into layered TiS2 [LixTiS2 (0 ≤ x ≤ 1)] and of potassium into the layers of graphite (C8K).
